div.head: MR. BIRRELL AND IRELAND. ADMINISTRATIVE DUBLIN COUNCIL.

div.p: Mr. Birrell will introduce an Irish Bill on the 7th May. It is understood that the Bill will establish a Council in Dublin composed of 100 members, 80 to be elected on parliament­ary franchise and 20 nominated. The Council will have wide administrative powers, includ­ing the administration of Irish estimates.

div.head: GERMANY AND PERSIA. THE BANK AGREEMENT.

div.p: The "National Gazette," commenting on the news published in the "Standard" regarding the bank agreement between Germany and Persia, says that according to information received from an authoritative source, no agreement has been concluded between Herr Stemrich, German Ambassador at Teheran, and the National Bank of Persia. However, it has been recognised for a long time that the Deutsche Orient Bank is extending its sphere of activity in Persia and its representative has actually started for Teheran, but until his arrival, the Bank cannot enter into any relations with the Persian Government.
(Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN POLICE VIOLENCE. PROTEST BY DUMA.

div.p: The Duma has adopted an interpellation of the Socialists against the violence of the police who violently put down a meeting of workmen, twenty persons being wounded, three fatally.
(Havas)
Through the interposition of the United States peace has been signed in Central America.
(Reuter)

(Reuter)

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: A new credit of L.E. 10,000 has been opened for the purpose of dealing with the plague.

div.head: Victims off Matarieh Fire.
div.p: It is said that the Ministry of Finance will exempt the inhabitants of Matarieh from all fishing dues for a period of one year.

div.head: Alexandria's Quays.
div.p: Oil Tuesday next, the 30th inst., the last block on the quays of the Eastern Harbour at Alexandria will be put in position.

div.head: Murder of a Coastguard
div.p: Yesterday morning a man of the coastguards at Sid Kreen, Mariout, was found to have been shot dead Enquiry proved the fact that he had been shot by a fellow coastguard with whom he was on bad terms, and the latter was immediately put under arrest.

div.head: The Economical Kitchens
div.p: Yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock "La Cuisine Economique" was inaugurated. This institution is destined to supply free meals to indigent pupils attending the Greek Schools at Chatby. It is to be erected at the expense of Mrs. Benachi and the site is adjoining the new Greek Orphanage. The Orthodox Patriarch, the Greek Consul and a representative gathering of Greek notables were present. The stone was laid by Mrs. Benachi.

div.head: Precautions at Cairo.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior is to be congratulated on the efficacy of the measures, which were taken on Wednesday evening to ensure the tranquil termination of the Mouled en-Nebi. Special police precautions to prevent any disturbance were taken and hundreds of mounted and foot police were in readiness All the tramcars on the Abbassieh line stopped running before 9 p.m.

div.head: Fatal Fireworks in Cairo
div.p: A terrible accident through the manufacturing of fireworks occurred at Cairo yesterday afternoon in the Fagallah quarter. A native workman was engaged in the factory when a violent explosion of gunpowder occurred and the man was hurled into the air and fell to the ground headless, his head being after­wards found some fifty metres away on a balcony. The explosion was followed by a fire and it was discovered that four little girls had been buried by the debris and burned to death.

div.head: Zizina Theatre
div.p: To-morrow evening a grand gala performance, organised by the pupils of Mr. Stefanos Christaki, professor of elocution, will be given at the Zizinia Theatre, this being Mr. Christaki's farewell appearance. The pieces given will be "Le Flibustier" by Richepin and "15 Heures de Fiaere," a two-act vaudeville by Clairville and Nuitter. The performance will begin at 9 p.m. and we are pleased to note that the intervals are not to exceed five minutes.

div.head: The Disconto-Gesellschaft
div.p: We draw the attention of our readers to the balance sheet of the Disconto-Gesellschaft of Berlin appearing in another column. For the year 1906 the Disconto-Gesellschaft of Berlin (with branches in London, Frankfort o. M. and Bremen) distributes a dividend of 9%, this being the same rate as for 1905, against 8 1/2% for the three previous years. The capital of Ml70,000,000 and Reserves of M 57,600,000 remain unchanged. According to the annual report just issued the business done during 1906 has grown materially, the total turnover including that of the Norddeutsche Bank in Hamburg, the whole of whose shares of M50,000,000 is held by the Disconto-Gesellschaft amounting to M51,263,000,000 against M154,000,000 in 1905.

The amounts deposited with the Disconto- Gesellschaft have increased from Ml10,049,000 in 1905 to M 153,384,000 in 1906, commissions earned from M5,824,000in 1905 to M6,264,000 in 1906 and in a corresponding manner each item of the balance sheet and of the profit And loss account shows extension.

div.head: AN INTERESTING CASE.
div.p: This morning the hall of the Appeal Court of the Mixed Tribunal at Alexandria presented a very animated appearance, for it was crowded with a large number of persons, who came to assist at the trial brought before the Italian Consulate by Mr M. Hernztein against 68 Italian subjects. These were accused of having signed a pamphlet charging the plaintiff with having given information which led to the arrest of the three Russians concerned in the recent affair which caused such commotion

Among the defendants were several nota­bilities of the Italian community among whom we noticed Drs. De Semo, Camerini, Protano, Calzolari and Salama. The inquiry lasted throughout the morning. All the defendants replied to the charge of defamation that they simply exposed facts in the brochure referred to in order that full light might be thrown up— on the case of the three Russians. All declared that they knew Mr. Hernztein by reputation only and that the charges were of public notoriety.

The Consular Court consisted of Falqui Cav. President, Com Manusardi and L Stagni, judge-assessors, Maltres Padoa Bey, Colucci, and Luzzato were tor the defence, and Maltre Volpini represented Mr. Hernztein, who ap­peared as "partie civile." The latter did not appear tin's morning, on the grounds of illness and at half past eleven the Court sent an usher with a doctor to confirm the plea of ill­ness. At the conclusion of the audience plain­tiffs counsel withdrew the charge against 22 or the defendants, thereby losing the case against the others according to Italian law. The counsels for the defence asked the Court to take note of the partial withdrawal of the case. The Court rose at midday and will sit at four o'clock this afternoon.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will arrive at Alexandria from Cairo on May 6 and will be followed by the Khedivah on the 9th prox.

div.head: THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: At the meeting of the Legislative Coun­cil held on Wednesday under the presi­dency of Abdul Hamid Pasha Sadik it was approved that the markaz tribunals should be enpowered to pronounce sentences of imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months or a fine of not more than L.10, whatever the maximum punishment under the act may be. The project regulating the expen­ses, bonuses and indemnities to be paid to doctors and veterniary surgeons when their services are required in cases of judicial and peneal character, was also approved.

div.head: THE RITZ HOTELS (EGYPT) LIMITED
div.p: At the meeting of the holders of Preferred Ordinary shares in the above Company, held yesterday in Cairo, it was decided that the Deferred shares of the company lie eon vet ted into Preferred Ordinary shares, and at the ex­traordinary general meeting of this Company, held immediately afterwards, the following decisions were arrived at:

I.That the business and affairs of the Com­pany should henceforth be managed and di­rected from Egypt and that, subject to con­firmation, the necessary alterations be made in the articles of association of the Company for that purpose.
II.That the agreement as to the compensa­tion for the London directors for loss of office he confirmed.
III. That article 107 in the articles of association be altered subject to confirmation.

It was, however, decided that the purchase of the land in the Garden City, Cairo, be not gone on with and that consequently all question of the increase of the capital would lie dropped in the meantime.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The express mall steamship Ismailia will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Wednesday 1st May for Pireaus, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.
The S.S. Imperial Prince, with passengers and general cargo from London, left Malta last night, and is due to arrive here on Monday.

div.head: FIRST SUMMER MEETING.
div.p: Yesterday was the first day of the first summer meeting of the Alexandria Sporting Club for this season, and a good afternoon's racing was witnessed though not under the best auspices. The cloudy morning was fortunately followed by a bright afternoon, but the wind was very chilly and as the attendance was poor the afternoon was distinctly "flat" Let us hope, however, that tomorrow the elements will be more kindly. From a racing point of view there was little fault to be found, the running being good and both riders and horses keen. A well-run event of the meeting was the race for the Municipality Chip which was secured by Batty on Jupiter for Messrs. A. J. Sursock and AJ Michaelidis in splendid style There were only three entries and the contest was very keen, Sadik leading the first round to be overhauled by Valentino at the commencement of the second round, and Valentino in his turn was run down by Jupiter, though not until the race was nearly finished The Galloway Plate, too, was very well run, the prize of P.T. 5,000 going to Khalil Pasha Khayat with Suleik, Jenkins up. The race for the Continental Stakes excited the greatest interest as it was one of the most important races ever run in Egypt- The race was for class 1 and 2, meaning English thoroughbreds or first class Egyptian country-breds. No less than sixteen English thoroughbreds were entered for the race and although many had to be scratched prior to the race a good field turned out, and the race, a mile and a half, was run in the splendid time of 2 minutes 34 seconds. The three year old country-bred. Red Cellar, acquitted himself remarkably well, coming in second to the big, upstanding five year old chestnut, Carlton Red Cedar is probably the finest raoe-horse bred in the country, being the son of Cedar, which was formerly raced in Egypt by Sir Eldon Gorst.

The start was good and for half the course the horses kept well together, Fadaan, Mikado, Radium and Hadeed being the four foremost. Round the last bend Fadaan looked like a winner but he was very cleverly challenged by Mikado, who was capitally ridden by Thompson, and who won in splendid style. Radium was a good third. |

div.p: Municipal Cup. — A cup value P.T. 5,000 presented by the Alexandria Municipality with P.T 5,000 added money, viz : P.T. 4,000 to ' the winner and P.T. 1,000 to 2nd horse. Handicap for Arabs Distance twice round the course. Entrance on 1st April 1907 P.T. 500. Messrs. A.J Sursock and A J. Michaelides' g.a.h. Jupiter, 8.12. Batty. 1

Sadik led at the start with Valentino second, Jupiter lying well behind, Half way round the course Valentino drew level with Sadik, Jupiter . still behind, but on coming round the bend Batty put on more speed and gradually drew up. As the winning post was passed the first time Valentino was a head and Jupiter on Sadik's heels. Jupiter then gradually drew up to Valentino and taking the lead kept it to the end, though a very hard effort was made by Valentino, who came in a very good second. Sadik was a very poor third.
Totalisator paid P.T. 69.

All the horses started well together and kept in a bunch for a good span. Before the bend Lahek had the lead but was overhauled in turn by Suleik, Chir, and Ghazi. Suleik and Chir had a good struggle for first place, which the former took. Lahek tried hard to come up with Ghazi for third place, but the latter secured it, though it just missed being a dead heat.

div.head: CAB STRIKE INCIDENT
div.p: A correspondent writes:

One of the most serious questions in Cairo at the present moment is as to how far the native police can be trusted in the case of any emergency When the cab strike was on I was looking out of my office window net far from the Telegraph Buildings in the Boulac- road. I noticed a European driving in a cab pursued by a number of low class natives, mostly youths. Several shawishes were in the immediate vicinity making a feeble pretence of protecting the cab and a patrol of mounted police with two officers were galloping to the cab's assistance and at that moment were about eighty yards from the cab. An Arab just then hurled a heavy lump of stone which narrowly missed the head of the European in the cab. It was sobig that if it had hit him the blow might easily have proved fatal. Any of the foot police could easily have arrested the man. But on the contrary they flagrantly allowed him to escape up a side street so as to avoid the mounted policemen, who, be it noted, had European officers with them. The European occupant of the cab jumped out of it and took refuge in the Telegraph Buildings and the cab returned under the protection of the mounted police. Ten minutes afterwards when die crowd had dispersed, the man, who had thrown the stone, was talking and laughing with the two shawishes on the very spot where re had committed the outrage.

There can be no doubt from this and similar instances which have occurred in Cairo of late, that the native police cannot be depended upon if unaccompanied by European officers or non-commissioned officers This incident emphasises the necessity of the large and immediate increase of the European element an all the police forces in the chief cities of Egypt.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Princess Nazli Hanem will leave Alexandria on Thursday next for Tunis by way of Messina.
Prince Mohamed Aly is expected to arrive in Cairo from Constantinople to-morrow.
The rumour that Yacoub Pasha Artin is to succeed Saba Pasha as Postmaster General is not officially confirmed.
The Countess de Serionne; M. Chevandier de Veldrome, M. Roux, and M. de Benoist have returned to Cairo after a journey on horseback from Helouan to Suez.
The Grand Sheikh of Al Azhar, Haasoun el Nawawi, paid a farewell visit to Lord Cromer at the British Agency on Wednesday.
M. Laloi, the new French judge, who will succeed Judge Prunieres at the Cairo Mixed Tribunals, will arrive In Egypt on the 15th proxo.
Lieut.-Col. E. R. O. Ludlow, commanding he A.S.C., and Capt. E. B. Bartlett, A.V.D., have arrived in Alexandria from Cairo on nspectien duty. -
Lieut. J. E. Gibbs, Coldstream Guards, has received three months' leave of absence.

div.head: REMARKABLE DISCOVERY
div.p: Some very interesting discoveries have just been made at the works now being carried out in order to extend Victoria House, opposite the British Consulate at Alexandria. Here was the supposed site of a great palace of the Ptolemies and while digging the foundations of the new building, Mr. Williams, the architect, was told by the workmen that the mouth of a mysterious opening in the ground had been, found at a depth of three metres below the surface. He ordered the opening to be cleaned out and then made his way into the cavity. He found after descending to the depth of five metres a large and well-built passage excavated in the sand stone rock. It extended f6r fifteen metres and was high enough to admit of a man penetrating into it standing upright At the end of this long passage a chamber was discovered, three metres in width and twelve metres in length. This room communicated with another of the same size and in a corner of the further chamber some steps cut in the solid rook were discovered. This stair­case communicated with the innermost chamber which was evidently an ancient burial place, for niches for lamps were ranged along the walls over which ran what appeared to be a Greek inscription, bat owing to the ruined state of the characters it is as yet indecipherable. The architect, Mr. Williams intends to make plans of this curious discov­ery. Meanwhile an opening has been left in the foundation walls from which access may be gained at any time. Anyone, who wants to explore these subterranean relics of the an­cient city, will have to get down by rope.

There is every probability that these passages and chambers are merely the prelude to a series of an underground network of commu­nications, which honeycomb, as is well-known, the greater part oi the modern city. Up to now there are many passages which have not as yet been penetrated in this neighbourhord.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday dull and windy and after midnight rain fell (0.03 in). This mornig opened bright with a clear sky and a light N.W. breeze. the barometer is rising.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vires et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a encore fléchi de 1/8 à 3 1/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a regagné 1/8 à 85 7/8; L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 102. La National Bank a perdu 3/8 à 24 et la Daïra 1/4 à 15 1/2. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée a a 8 3/4 et la Delta Light à 10 1 2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a reculé de 4 francs à 723. La Banque d'Athènes a avancé do 1 franc à 124.

Ici, le marché a été aujourd'hui ce qu'il fut hier, c'est-à-dire à peu près nul. II y a eu une trentaine de transactions enregistrées, qui ont été naturellement pratiquées aux cours de compensation fixés le 12 Avril courant et mo­difiés en légère partie le lendemain. Comme il est interdit de vendre au-dessous de ces cours, il devient manifeste qu'il y a encore des ache­teurs, ou bien qu'on se couvre aux prix indi­qués, ce qui est, sans conteste, rassurant.

Au reste, la situation générale du marché nous disons la situation du marché et nen la situation d'aucuns — n'a jamais été alarmante, encore qu'elle ait donné lieu, comme partout, à des inquiétudes légitimes à la suite de la récente crise universelle.

Aussi bien, en présence de la stagnation qu'elles déterminent, on est porté à contester l'opportunité des mesures extraordinaires prises pour enrayer la baisse, ou plutôt pour contre­carrer les manceuvres des baissiers. On allègue que ces mesures pourraient être mal interpré­tées à l'étranger et jeter le discrédit sur le marché égyptien. On cite à l'appui les ordres de vente transmis d'ici qui ont eu, hier encore, une fâcheuse influence sur les cours de la Na­tional Bank, de la Daïra et du Crédit Foncier, à fondras et à Paris. On en conclut que le système " du laisser faire, du laisser passer " vaudrait mieux que les restrictions imposées, restrictions qui pourraient faire supposer in justement que le marché égyptien est endan­ger, d'autant pins que lefond de baisse est plus ou moins atteint, qu'il n'y a pas, en tout cas, à appréhender de fortes dépressions addition­elles ; que beaucoup de titres pourraient même bénéficier d'une reprise si l'on revenait au régime libre, etc.

Nous nous bornons, pour notre part, à ex­poser ces observations. Elles méritent d'être sérieusement étudiées par les promoteurs de " l'essai loyal " patronné par les Comités des Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie. Cet essai, hâtons-nous de le reconnaître, a été entrepris avec les meilleures intentions du monde et il n'a nui jusqu'à présent à aucun intérêt parti­culier, ce qui n'est pas peu dire. Quelques amendements immédiats, de nature à pérmettre reprise des affaires, suffiraient peut-être à rendre conforme à l'intérêt général.
On nous écrit de Londres, à la date du 19 Avril courant :

" Au Stock Exchange, la semaine a été en­core très inactive pour les valeurs égyptiennes; mais la tendance, qui était faible dans les pre­miers jours, s'est quelque peu améliorée depuis hier. La plupart des ordres reçus d'Egypte sont restés inexécutés et les cours sont nominaux pour l'instant, les transactions devenant de moins en moins nombreuses et les affaires de plus en plus difficiles.

" Les Estates ont baissé jusqu'à £ 1 11/16 pour remonter à 1 7/8 et clôturer ce soir à 1 13/16 ; leurs parts de fondateur ont été échangés à £16. Les New Egyptian ont été absolument calmes et plutôt faibles malgré la nouvelle de la vente du domaine de Matins J'apprends à ce sujet que la Compagnie se propose de répartir À bref délai un dividende de 12 1/2 pour cent, soit 2 sh. 6 par action. Les United Lands ont baissé à £ 0 7/8 pour re­monter au pair et clôturer à 0 15/16.

" La Banque d'Angleterre n'a pas abaissé son taux d'escompte cette semaine ; mais on s'attend à ee qu'elle le réduise bientôt à A % en présence des prix de 3 1/2 pour cent et au-dessous qui se pratiquent sur le marché libre. "

Nous détachons de la correspondance de Londres du "Moniteur des Intérêts Matériels" de Bruxelles du 19 Avril le passage suivant : " La démission de lord Cromer des hautes fonctions qu'il remplissait depuis si longtemps et d'une façon si remarquable en Egypte n'a affecté en rien les rentes égyptiennes, car le Stock Exchange est persuadé que l'oeuvre ac­complie par cet homme l'Etat est suffisamment solide pour se maintenir et porter ses fruits sans l'appui de la présence personnelle de son auteur. L'Egypte est engagée dans la voie de la prospérité ; rien ne menace de l'en faire dévier.''
Les actionnaires de l'ibrahinieh Ploughing Co. sont convoqués en assemblée générale ex­traordinaire pour le15 Mai prochain, à 4 h.p.m, au siège social au Caire.

A l'ordre du jour : 1°. Rapport du conseil d'administration ; 2*. Emission de 1905 ; sen­tence arbitrale ; 3*. Accord avec la Societe Générale des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte ; 4i*. Mesures à prendre ; éventuellement liqui­dation de la Société.
Le dépôt des titres doit être effectué avant le 6 Mai 1907,

div.head: Sudan Government
NOTICE.
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labour yers in presence of an official or other reliable witnesses.

Shareholders who hold Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Com­pany they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement in writ­ing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, re., not later than the 4th May, or in Egypt with the National Bank of Egypt, the Bank of Egypt, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, Crédit Lyonnais, or the Imperial Ottoman Bank, ten clear days before the date of the meeting, i.e., not later than 26th April, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be. produced by the holders attending the Meeting. 30132-2 1

div.head: EGYPTAIN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT.
INCREASE OF CAPITAL.
CONTROL BEING TRANSFERED TO CAIRO.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company Ltd., was held on Tuesday the 18th inst., a Winchester House, Old Broad-street, EC., Sir Auckland Colvin, K.C.S I., K.C.M.G., C I E (the Chairman of the company), presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. F. J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting,

The Chairman said : Gentlemen,-.When we met on the 19th July last year certain alterations in the memorandum and articles of association of our company were put before you for your consideration and approval, and were subsequently passed and confirmed at the general meeting held in August. At that time then was a proposal before our company to amalgamate with the Egyptian Land and General Trust Company, and in order to carry that proposal into effect we were informed by our legal advisers that it would be necessary to alter the terms of our memorandum of association so as to extend the area of our operations which was at that time limited to the Delta as we are aware the proposal to acquire the Egyptian Land and General Trust Company fell through, but though the same actual necessity did not exist, it was still deemed desirable to proceed with the alteration to this memorandum, and an application was duly made to the Courts to obtain their approval to such proposed alteration The order of the Court, which reached us in January of this year, was to the effect that before any change in the memorandum of association could be sanctioned the name of the Delta Land Company must be altered Meanwhile, the rail way company had sold their shares in the land company, as not being authorised to hold shares in another company having such extended objects, and so much of this articles of the Delta Land Company as provided for the participation of the Delta Light Rail ways on their Board; and in their affairs, has been cancelled, and in pursuance of the revision of the articles sanctioned by you, the land company became an entirely independent body, and its connection with the railway company was put an end to. On learning the order of the Court, it was ascertained by me, being at that time in Egypt, that most of the share-holders of the land company, a large majority; of the shares of which are held in Egypt, were entirely adverse to the change of name of our company, believing that it would be injurious to its credit and stability. As the proposal for the acquisition of the Egyptian Land are General Trust Company had fallen through the more urgent necessity of altering the memorandum of association no longer existed (the company proposing mainly to confine it operations in future to the neighbourhood of Cairo), and I was urged to take no further action in the application before the Court ; at the same time it was intimated to me that, in view of the changed circumstances, it was, as far as could be ascertained, the unanimous; desire of the shareholders of the land comped in Egypt to revert to the status quo ante, an to reestablish the connection which had existed between it and the Egyptian Delta Light Railways prior to the negotiations which led up to the meeting of 20th July. I am, as you are probably aware, also the Chairman of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, and I ascertained that the wishes of the shareholders of the land company coincided with that of the Egyptian section of the Board of the railway and subsequently, on my return to England the assent of the London section of the railway Board was accorded to the proposed reversion to the former connection between the two companies.
CONSTITUTION OF THE BOARD.

You are probably aware that by the original articles of association of the land company, to which it is now proposed to revert, four of the seven members of the Board of the land company must be directors of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, should they be willing to take their seats on the Land Board. Now the whole business of the land company is of an exceptional nature. It is concerned solely with local transactions in the purchase of land and buildings in Egypt, of the merits of which the London section of the Railways Board is necessarily, to a great extent, imperfectly informed It needs no such expert advice or technical assistance in London as is required, for example, by such an enterprise as a railway or a steamship service. So long as the two companies were associated, constant references between the members of the land company in Cairo and the London directors of the railways, sitting on the Land Board, have nevertheless been found necessary, and the London members were put to disadvantage by their want of intimate acquaintance with the conditions existing in Egypt and consequently with the merits of the policy as of the several propositions from time to time put before them. Considerable delay has been thus caused, and the affairs of your company necessarily suffered ; the more so that, as you are aware, great competition exists in Egypt in regard to the purchase of land and building and decisions have often to be taken at brief notice, or valuable properties may be lost. When, therefore, the question of re-association between the Boards of the two companies can before the Railways Board, it was unanimous! agreed that it would be more in the interest of the land company, as of the railways, whir holds a considerable number of shares in the land company, that the representatives of the railways on the Land Board should be members of the Egyptian section of the Delta Light Railways Board and not of the London section of the Board. The Egyptian members of the Railways Board have every means of adequate­ly informing themselves of the several propo­sals put before the Land Board, and, unlike the London members of the Railway Board on the Land Board, are as cognisant of the merits of the various questions from time to time sub­mitted to them us are the members in Egypt of the Land Board themselves. By a parity of reasoning it is evident that in the interests of the land company, the members of the Land Board should also be resident in Egypt. If, then, members of the Land Board, whether they were members sitting as delegates for the railways or members of the Land Board proper, were to meet in future in Cairo, it followed that it would be necessary for the conduct of that business that all future meetings, of whatever kind, should be held in Cairo, and that the business of the land company should be transferred to Egypt, the company remaining meanwhile a British company, having in London the registered office and a secretary, but in all other respects transacting its business in Cairo, and not in London. There was the less objection to this course being pursued, in that the Delta Land Company has no debenture debt in London, and there could, therefore, be no objection anticipated on behalfof debenture holders, who otherwise might justly have regarded transfer of control to Egypt as an infringement of the conditions in which they had placed their funds at the disposal of the company. Resolutions one and two are drawn with a view to reverting to the old connection between the land company and the railway company. Resolution number three is with a view to transferring the management and direction of the business of the company to Egypt. This is all I have to say with regard to this branch of the subject You will understand, I think, from what I have said that the links between the two companies which were severed in July lastwill now, with your approval, be reconstituted; that the Delta Light Railways will, as before,

continue to have four seats, should it wish to claim them, on the Delta Land Board, but that the Land Board so reconstituted will in future meet in Cairo and not in London and that its business will be carried on wholly there, while it remains itself a London company, with a registered office and secretary in London.
THE PROPOSED CAPITAL INCREASE.

With regard to the proposed increase of capital, which is dealt with by Resolution IV., it is necessary to explain to you that the land company have before them a project for acquiring a considerable area of land lying between Cairo and Helouan, in the immediate vicinity of a valuable and larger tract already acquired s by them in previous years. Both properties are known as the Meadi properties. The object of the company is to round off the whole of these two properties and to convert them into residential properties, in the belief that such sites will be largely in demand by residents in Cairo and that the sale of the several lots of which have been and are being already divided will be of considerable value to the company, it Some progress has already been made in the sale of sites on the Meadi land previously is accquired by the company and negotiations are now pending with a group who own the balance of land above referred to for acquiring their property It may be of interest to you to know that when I was recently in Egypt I inquired personally into the merits of the project to which I refer and satisfied myself that, so far as can be ascertained, in the present condition of affairs in Egypt, where much building and land speculation is rife, the Meadi property, which is situated on the Light Railways, a few miles from Cairo, on the line of railway to Helouan, fulfils the conditions which are necessary to make it a popular suburb of Cairo. I understand that a very competent general manager has been appointed by the land company since I was there to carry out without delay the measures necessary to hasten the development of the Meadi prop­erty and that members of the Land Board as so about to be constituted are sanguine that the enterprise will be very successful and are prepared to devote to it the care and energy in which characterise them. You will gather from what I have said that, in common with the other London members of the Land Board, as reconstituted in July last, I must necessarily tender my resignation so soon as you have given your sanction to the proposals now put before you and a confirmatory meeting has been held to ratify them.
THE PROPOSAL STATED BRIEFLY.

Let me repent in a few words the substance of what I have said. My colleagues and I, in agreeing to put the matter before a general meeting in London, have been largely guided by the fact that the majority of the capital , invested in this company has been subscribed in Egypt : that there is no debenture debt held in London : that by far the greater part of the shareholders are resilient in Egypt; that the presence of directors of the light railways on the Land Board will strengthen your Board ; and that to carry out the enterprise of the peculiarly local and limited nature of the ,n Egyptian Land Company in the conditions which are necessary to success the best means of securing the local knowledge and unanimity in which are necessary to that end, will, in our opinion, be found in the creation of a single Board, sitting in Cairo, constituted in the manner which I have explained to you. Before putting the resolutions to the meeting I shall be glad to answer any questions you may wish to put to me or to give you any further information in my power.
Mr. T. P. Singer asked whether any members of the present London Board would in future serve on the Board in Egypt.
The Chairman ; No.
Mr. Singer said that being so, it did not appear to him that there would be any contin­uity from the present Board to the new Board in Egypt.

The Chairman replied that there would not be individually, but the four members who rep­resented the railway on the Cairo Board had always, as members of the Delta Light Rail­ways, been cognisant of all negotiations which had been carried on from time to time by the Land Company. Further answering Mr. Singer, the Chairman said that one of the new mem­bers of the Board would represent the property about to be purchased from the group referred to ; Mr. Williamson had for some time past seen a member of the Delta Land Board, and it would be for the Land Board to appoint the third member. There were obviously practical difficulties in the way of one of the members of the Board being in London, which had been already explained. If they had any they must have more than one. No meetings would be held in London, and the present London mem­bers, after all, spent a very short time in Egypt—two months a year at the outside. A. minority of directors in London would have to accept responsibility for decisions arrived at in their absence, they being unable to exert any effective control over such decisions ; and it would be difficult to find directors who were willing to accept that responsibility. It was better that men on the spot, who were able to inform themselves of all the details, from time to time, should be responsible.
THE RESOLUTIONS.
The Chairman then proposed the first of the special resolutions to which he had already re­ferred, and which, he added, were subject to confirmation at a meeting to be subsequently convened :—
That the special resolution of the company passed on the 19th day of July, 1906, and confirmed on the 16th day of August, 1906, to the effect following :—

That the memorandum and articles of asso­ciation be varied as follows.—1. By strik­ing out from Section 3, sub-section (a) of the memorandum of association the words " in any district," and by substi­tuting for the words " in which the railways belonging to or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd., or any ex­tension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed, or proposed to be constructed, may serve or be intended to serve " occurring in the same sub­section the words " or in the Sudan "
be and is hereby cancelled.
Major W. I. Le Breton seconded the res­olution, which was carried unanimously.
The Chairman next moved :—
That the articles of association as altered by special resolutions passed and confirmed on the 19th July, 1906, and the 16th August, 1906, respectively, be varied as follows : —

(a)Art. 75—By adding next after the word "seven" occurring at the end thereof the words "and every exercise of the power to appoint directors shall be sub­ject to the condition that a majority at least of the directors shall always be directors or local directors of the Egyp­tian Delta Light Railways, Ltd., while any such person be qualified and willing to act."
(b)Art. 81—By inserting next after the words " by the Board for election " the words " or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd,"

(c)Art, 85—By adding next after the words " he is so interested " appearing in line 5 thereof the words- " Provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any contract dealing or transaction with the .Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd."

(d)Art. 86—By adding next after the word " vacant " occurring in such article the words " If any director appointed by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd„ as a first director, or subsequently under this article shall cease to be a director, otherwise than by retirement by rotation, and on retiring by rotation shall not thereupon be re-elected, the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd., may by writing delivered within one month of his ceasing to be a director, at a place in Egypt to be appointed by the Board, or at the registered office of this company, nominate a successor, and on such nomin­ation with a consent in writing by the person nominated to act being so deliver­ed, the parson nominated, if qualified, shall become a director, and shall take the place of the director to whom he succeeds."
(e)Art 87—By inserting at the commence­ment thereof before the word "Any" the words "Save as aforesaid."
(f)Art 90—By inserting next after the words "in Egypt" the words "provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd."
This was seconded by Major-General H.J. Hallowes, and carried unanimously.
The Chairman further moved :—

That it is desirable that the business and affairs of the company should henceforth be managed and directed entirely from Egypt, and that accordingly the articles of association as altered by special resolutions passed and confirmed on the 19th July, 1906, and the 16th August, 1908, respectively, be further varied as follows :—
(a)Art. 4—By inserting next after the word "Board" first occurring therein, the words "in Cairo."
(b)Art. 27—By striking out the words "A local hoard or agent abroad" and all subsequent words.
(c) Art. 28—By inserting next after the word "kept" the words "in Cairo."
(d)Art. 43—By inserting next before the

This resolution was seconded by Mr. H. D. Moule, and unanimously adopted.
The Chairman : I now have to propose the two ordinary resolutions, the reasons for which I have already explained. The first is : —
That the capital of the company be and is hereby increased from £250,000 to £500,000.
Major W. I. Le Breton seconded the resolution, which was carried.
The Chairman also moved : —

That the directors be and are hereby authorised to enter into an agreement with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd., wherebyit shall be agreed that clauses 3 and 4 of an agreement dated the 21st day of April, 1904, and made between the company of the one part, and the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd., of the other part, which said clauses I were cancelled by a letter dated the 27th July, 1906, shall be restored so as again to be of full I force and effect.
This was seconded by Major-General H. J. Hallowes, and adopted, and the proceedings terminated.

div.p: The List will open on APRIL 26th 1907 at 10 o'clock a.m. and dose on APRIL 27th at 12 o'clock noon.
The Banque de Salonique recieve Subscriptions at Cairo and Alexandria.
The Cairo Sand Bricks Company
LIMITED.
(Incorporated under The English Companies Acts, 1862 to 1900.)
Capital, £stg. 100,000,
DIVIDED INTO

The profits of the Company made during the financial Year or other period comprised in the Accounts submitted to the Ordinary General Meeting in each year with any profits' carried forward from past years shall be applicable in order of priority and manner following: — 1. Five per cert of such profits shall be carried to a Reserve Fund but so that whenever such Reserve Fund shall amount to fifty per cent of the paid up Capital of the Company this provision shall cease to apply.
2 The balance shall be applied to the payment of a non-cumulative preferential Dividend for such period at the rate of six per cent per annum on the Capital paid up on the Ordinary' Shares.

3. Of the surplus ten per cent shall he said to the Directors as remuneration for their services 60 per cent shall be applicable to the payment of a further dividend on the Capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares or may be carried to Reserve or otherwise dealt with as the Company in General Meeting determines and 30 per cent shall be divided rateably among the Holders of the Founders Shares.
In case of a winding up any surplus assets after repayment of Capital shall be divided as to 60 per cent among the the Ordinary Shares in proportion to the number held
and as to 40 per cent among the Holders of the Founders Shares rateably.
Issue of 98,750 Ordinary Shares and 25,000 Founders Shares of which 35,000 Ordinary Shares and 1,750 Founders Shares are now offered for public subscription payable as follows :
Ordinary Shares 10/- per 8hare on Application,
10 - per 8hare on Allotment.
Founders 8hares 1- per 8hare on Application.
Each Subscriber for Ordinary Shares will be entitled to apply for and receive an allotment at par of One Founders Share in respect of every complete 20 Ordinary Shares allotted to him.

Of the remaining shares 8,250 Founders Shares have been subscribed for in the Memorandum of Association by Frederick Maurice Singer and will be allotted at par to him and he has by the Memorandum of Association guaranteed the Subscription of 54,000 Ordinary Shares of which number he and his friends will take firm 19,500 Ordinary Shares as appears in Agreement No. 2 hereinafter mentioned. 44,250 Ordinary Shares and 15,000 Founders Shares will be allotted credited os fully paid under Agreement No. 1 hereinafter referred to.
The allotment will be mane at the discretion of the Board.

Head Office Abbassia, Cairo.
PROSPECTUS.
The Company has been formed for the objects mentioned in its Memorandum of Association and more especially for the purchase and development and extension of the Abbassia Sand Bricks Company G m.b H.

The Abbassia Sand Brick Company G. m; b. H. (hereinafter called the Old Company) was started about two years ago to meet the increasing demand in Cairo and its suburbs for bricks and building materials. A factory was set up by the Old Company and the main work of this factory was the manufacture of sand-bricks.

These bricks are made of a mixture of sand and lime (both of which materials are found in abundance in close proximity to the factory) and possess many excellent building qualities. They are more durable and offer a greater power of resistance than the ordinary clay brick and at the same time they can be turned out ready for immediate use in a far shorter space of time.

These advantages are naturally appreciated by building and construction firms and companies and large contracts have already been fulfilled for some of the most important of these in Cairo and its suburbs

The Semiramis Hotel is built of sand bricks furnished by the Old Company, and a contract has already been entered into for supplying sand-bricks for the new Ritz Hotel that is shortly to be erected at Garden City, Kasr-el-Aine, Cairo. Orders have also been received from the Heliopolis Oasis Company, from the contractor for the new barracks at Abbassia and other important building and contracting firms.
In short so many orders have been taken and so many demands have been-made on the Old Company that it has been found impossible to fulfil them all with the present factory.

It has been decided therefore to form toe Cairo Sand Bricks Company Limited (hereinafter called the New Company) to take overall assets and liabilities of the Old Company as from the 31st day of December 1906 and with the increased capital that will be provided to considerably enlarge the factory already in existence
In this way it is hoped that the output will be more than doubled and that substantial profits will consequently accrue to the New Company.

The purchase price to be paid for the business and goodwill of the Old Company has been fixed at Lst, 45.000. This sum will be satisfied by the allotment of fully paid Ordinary and Founders Shares of the New Company as is shown by Agreement No. 1 set out hereunder. For this price the new Company will acquire some &5O0 square metres of land at Abbassia and the plant, machinery, fixtures, etc. of the old Company. Further it will take over the benefit of all contracts entered into by the Old Company in the ordinary course of its business as well as all its liabilities subsequent to the 31st December 1906.

The situation of the site of the factory is in the Directors' opinion in every way an excellent one. The necessary material for the manufacture of the bricks is close at hand and in the matter of transport the factory possesses exceptional facilities having at its doors a secondary line of the State Railways and a Branch line of the Delta Light Railways Company. Further lying as it does between Cairo and the Heliopolis Oasis delivery by road to either of these important building centres can be easily effected.
The Vendors to and the promoters of the New Company are the Old Company and the following contract has been entered into by them with the New Company.

N° 1. AGREEMENT dated the 10th day of April 1907 and made between the Old Company whose registered office is situated at Alexandria of the one part and the New Company of the other part whereby the New Company have the right to acquire from the Old Company as from the 1st day of January 1907 subject to the liabilities of the Old Company subsequent to that date its land and buildings at Abbassia and all its plant stock machinery implement materials and good-will for the sum of Lst. 45,000 to be satisfied by the allotment to the Old Company of 44,250 Ordinary Shares of Lst. 1 each and 15.000 Founders Shares of One Shilling each of the New Company all credited as fully paid. Of this amount no sum is payable for goodwill.

div.head: The Articles of Association contain the following provsions :
div.p: Art. 85. — The qualification of a Director shall be the holding of Ordinary Shares of the Company to the nominal value of Lst. '200.

Art. 86. — As remuneration for their services each Director shall be paid a fixed salary at the rate of Lst 50 per annum. And the Directors shall also be paid collectively the share of surplus profits mentioned in Art 120 (being the 10% hereinbefore referred to) and such remuneration shall be divided among them in such proportions and manner as they may determine and in default of such determination equally.
Art. 99. — The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be a Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company.

Art 102. — The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits or by any or all of those modes. A Managing Director shall unless otherwise determined be entitled to remuneration as a Director.

Art. 111. — If any of the Directors shall be called upon to perform extra services or to travel or reside in any part of the world for any of the purposes of the Company or the business thereof the Company shall remunerate the Director or Directors so doing in such manner as may be determined by the Directors and such remuneration may ^ be either in addition to or in substitution for his or their share in the remuneration hereinbefore provided for the Directors.
The Minimum Subscription on which the Directors may proceed to Allotment is fixed by the Articles of Association at 25 per cent of the shares offered for subscription.

As before mentioned Mr. Frederick Maurice Singer has in the Memorandum of Association guaranteed the subscription of 54.500 Ordinary Shares and he has formed a Syndicate of Guarantee who by the terms of an Agreement dated 2nd April 1907 (herein referred to as agreement N° 2) have agreed to take firm 19.500 Ordinary Shares and to guarantee the subscription by the public of 35.000 Ordinary Shares. For this the members of the said Syndicate of Guarantee will be entitled to call for and receive a transfer from Mr. F.M. Singer at par of the respective numbers of Founders Shares set out in the said agreement opposite to their respective names
Other than this no commission will be paid by the Company for underwriting.
The preliminary expenses Are estimated at list 1.000 and will be paid by the Company.

Copies of the above mentioned agreements together with a print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company (a copy of which Memorandum is printed on the back of this prospectus and forms part thereof) may be seen at the Banque de Salonique at any time during business hours before the list of subscription is closed.
Of the Directors the following are interested in the formation of the Company.
Mr. Paul Hahnloser has a five twefths and Mr. Albert Baechler a seven seventy fifths interest in the profits of the Old Company.

The following Directors are members of the Syndicate of Guarantee above mentioned. They will take firm the number of the Ordinary Shares set out in the first column hereunder opposite their respective names and will guarantee the subscription by the public of the number of Ordinary Shares set out in the second column hereunder opposite their respective names. For this they will receive a transfer at par from Mr. F.M. Singer of the number of Founders Shares set out in the third column hereunder opposite their respective names while Mr. F.M. Singer will retain the number of Founders shares set opposite his name.

Application for Shares should be made on accompanying forms and torwarded with a cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no Allotment is made the application money will be returned in full and wire the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the applicants.
Failure to pay any instalments when due will render the previous payments liable to forfeiture.
Copies of this Prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the Banque de Salonique at Cairo and Alexandria.
Dated 22nd April 1907.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
AVIS
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration de la National Bank of Egypt, a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance des intéressés que l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire des Actionnaires réunie le 11 Avril 1907, au siège social, au Caire, a fixé à 18 shillings par action le montant du dividende à payer pour l'exercice 1906. Ce dividende est payable à partir du 15 Avril 1907, contre remise du coupon No. 7, a la Na­tional Bank, au Caire, a la Succursale d'Alex­andrie, dans les Agences des Provinces de la National Bank et a ses bureaux de Londres, 4A5. King William Street.

div.head: General Administration of Wakfs.
NOTICE.
div.p: Offers will be received at the office of the Wakfs' Delegation at Ohizeh, situated on the west of the Pont des Anglais, on the 9th day of May 1907 from 9 a.m. to midday and from 2 to 4 p.m.. for the sale by public auction of one feddan, nine kirats, and twelve sahms situated at Ghizeh, at hod Chagaret Gaddonah. This land is about 280 metres distant from the north of the Pyramid embankment and about 15 metres west of the railway line to Upper Egypt.
The upset price of the said land in block is already fixed at L E. 2,256.

Applicants must either call personally or by proxy at the said office on the day and at the times designated above to inform them­selves of the conditions of contract for this deal and afterwards make their offer.
All offers must be accompanied by a guar­antee amount to 20% of the sum of the said upset price.
Offers made after stated date And times or not accepted by the guarantee stipulated will not be accepted.
